mdRecord.dcterms:description: Commissioned in 1939 by journalist Loren Pope and his wife Charlotte Pope, one of the first Usonian houses designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. It was completed in 1941, located at 1005 Locust Street, Falls Church, Virginia. In 1946, the Popes sold the home to Robert and Marjorie Leighey for $17,000. In 1964, the Virginia Department of Highways declared that the house would be condemned to make way for Interstate 66. Robert had passed away in 1963; Marjorie donated the home to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, who granted her the right to remain there for the rest of her life in return. The house was ultimately dismantled, moved, and reconstructed on another piece of property owned by the National Trust: Woodlawn Plantation, a 2,000 acre property in Alexandria, Virginia which was once part of George Washington's estate. -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pope%E2%80%93Leighey_House [work]
